      47             : /*
      48             :  * Given a hash value and the size of the hash table, find the bucket
      49             :  * in which the hash value belongs. Since the hash table must contain
      50             :  * a power-of-2 number of elements, this is a simple bitmask.
      51             :  */
      52             : #define HASH_INDEX(h, sz) ((Index) ((h) & ((sz) - 1)))

     160             : 
     161             : /*
     162             :  * Hash and equality functions for system types that are used as cache key
     163             :  * fields.  In some cases, we just call the regular SQL-callable functions for
     164             :  * the appropriate data type, but that tends to be a little slow, and the
     165             :  * speed of these functions is performance-critical.  Therefore, for data
     166             :  * types that frequently occur as catcache keys, we hard-code the logic here.
     167             :  * Avoiding the overhead of DirectFunctionCallN(...) is a substantial win, and
     168             :  * in certain cases (like int4) we can adopt a faster hash algorithm as well.
     169             :  */
     170             :

     581             : /*
     582             :  *  CatCacheInvalidate
     583             :  *
     584             :  *  Invalidate entries in the specified cache, given a hash value.
     585             :  *
     586             :  *  We delete cache entries that match the hash value, whether positive
     587             :  *  or negative.  We don't care whether the invalidation is the result
     588             :  *  of a tuple insertion or a deletion.
     589             :  *
     590             :  *  We used to try to match positive cache entries by TID, but that is
     591             :  *  unsafe after a VACUUM FULL on a system catalog: an inval event could
     592             :  *  be queued before VACUUM FULL, and then processed afterwards, when the
     593             :  *  target tuple that has to be invalidated has a different TID than it
     594             :  *  did when the event was created.  So now we just compare hash values and
     595             :  *  accept the small risk of unnecessary invalidations due to false matches.
     596             :  *
     597             :  *  This routine is only quasi-public: it should only be used by inval.c.
     598             :  */
     599             : void
     600    18523004 : CatCacheInvalidate(CatCache *cache, uint32 hashValue)
     601             : {
     602             :     Index       hashIndex;
     603             :     dlist_mutable_iter iter;
     604             : 
     605             :     CACHE_elog(DEBUG2, "CatCacheInvalidate: called");
     606             : 
     607             :     /*
     608             :      * We don't bother to check whether the cache has finished initialization
     609             :      * yet; if not, there will be no entries in it so no problem.
     610             :      */
     611             : 
     612             :     /*
     613             :      * Invalidate *all* CatCLists in this cache; it's too hard to tell which
     614             :      * searches might still be correct, so just zap 'em all.
     615             :      */
     616    18626422 :     dlist_foreach_modify(iter, &cache->cc_lists)
     617             :     {
     618      103418 :         CatCList   *cl = dlist_container(CatCList, cache_elem, iter.cur);
     619             : 
     620      103418 :         if (cl->refcount > 0)
     621         144 :             cl->dead = true;
     622             :         else
     623      103274 :             CatCacheRemoveCList(cache, cl);
     624             :     }
     625             : 
     626             :     /*
     627             :      * inspect the proper hash bucket for tuple matches
     628             :      */

     630    24800974 :     dlist_foreach_modify(iter, &cache->cc_bucket[hashIndex])
     631             :     {
     632     6277970 :         CatCTup    *ct = dlist_container(CatCTup, cache_elem, iter.cur);

     758             :  *  tuples very likely now have different TIDs than before.  (At one point
     759             :  *  we also tried to force re-execution of CatalogCacheInitializeCache for
     760             :  *  the cache(s) on that catalog.  This is a bad idea since it leads to all
     761             :  *  kinds of trouble if a cache flush occurs while loading cache entries.
     762             :  *  We now avoid the need to do it by copying cc_tupdesc out of the relcache,
     763             :  *  rather than relying on the relcache to keep a tupdesc for us.  Of course
     764             :  *  this assumes the tupdesc of a cachable system table will not change...)

    1396             :      * will eventually age out of the cache, so there's no functional problem.

    1915             : /*
    1916             :  * CatalogCacheCreateEntry
    1917             :  *      Create a new CatCTup entry, copying the given HeapTuple and other
    1918             :  *      supplied data into it.  The new entry initially has refcount 0.
    1919             :  *
    1920             :  * To create a normal cache entry, ntp must be the HeapTuple just fetched
    1921             :  * from scandesc, and "arguments" is not used.  To create a negative cache
    1922             :  * entry, pass NULL for ntp and scandesc; then "arguments" is the cache
    1923             :  * keys to use.  In either case, hashValue/hashIndex are the hash values
    1924             :  * computed from the cache keys.
    1925             :  *
    1926             :  * Returns NULL if we attempt to detoast the tuple and observe that it

    1928             :  * retry the tuple lookup in that case.

    2119             : 
    2120             : /*
    2121             :  *  PrepareToInvalidateCacheTuple()
    2122             :  *
    2123             :  *  This is part of a rather subtle chain of events, so pay attention:
    2124             :  *
    2125             :  *  When a tuple is inserted or deleted, it cannot be flushed from the
    2126             :  *  catcaches immediately, for reasons explained at the top of cache/inval.c.
    2127             :  *  Instead we have to add entry(s) for the tuple to a list of pending tuple
    2128             :  *  invalidations that will be done at the end of the command or transaction.
    2129             :  *
    2130             :  *  The lists of tuples that need to be flushed are kept by inval.c.  This
    2131             :  *  routine is a helper routine for inval.c.  Given a tuple belonging to
    2132             :  *  the specified relation, find all catcaches it could be in, compute the
    2133             :  *  correct hash value for each such catcache, and call the specified
    2134             :  *  function to record the cache id and hash value in inval.c's lists.
    2135             :  *  SysCacheInvalidate will be called later, if appropriate,
    2136             :  *  using the recorded information.
    2137             :  *
    2138             :  *  For an insert or delete, tuple is the target tuple and newtuple is NULL.
    2139             :  *  For an update, we are called just once, with tuple being the old tuple
    2140             :  *  version and newtuple the new version.  We should make two list entries
    2141             :  *  if the tuple's hash value changed, but only one if it didn't.
    2142             :  *
    2143             :  *  Note that it is irrelevant whether the given tuple is actually loaded
    2144             :  *  into the catcache at the moment.  Even if it's not there now, it might
    2145             :  *  be by the end of the command, or there might be a matching negative entry
    2146             :  *  to flush --- or other backends' caches might have such entries --- so
    2147             :  *  we have to make list entries to flush it later.
    2148             :  *
    2149             :  *  Also note that it's not an error if there are no catcaches for the
    2150             :  *  specified relation.  inval.c doesn't know exactly which rels have
    2151             :  *  catcaches --- it will call this routine for any tuple that's in a
    2152             :  *  system relation.
    2153             :  */
    2154             : void
    2155     2365970 : PrepareToInvalidateCacheTuple(Relation relation,
    2156             :                               HeapTuple tuple,
